fol.24r
6 January M
r
Bodly
Elizabeth R
By the Queen.
Trustie and welbeloved we greet you well. Where of late we
did by o
r
Letters will you to impart both to the
States generall
,
and
Councell of State
o
r
disposition for the ayd of
the French
kinge
, to have the use of some of o
r
bandes of footemen being there
in o
r
pay, to be by us employed in some service against the Spani-
ardes that have invaded
Brittanyne
and to obtayn their liking
and assent thereunto, Wherein we hope you ha
ve
accomplished o
r
commandement: We doe now for execution of this o
r
necessary
purpose being proffitable both for those Cuntries and ours, but of
all others most necessary for the french kinge, send o
r
trustie an
d
welbeloved servant
S
r
John Norris
knight to renew this o
r
former
request to the states, and consequently to make choice out of all
companies serving there of the number of three thousand foo
te
in orderly bandes, and them to take into his charge and to cond
[.]
them by sea as we have directed him Wherefore we have comm
anded
him to make you thoroughly acquainted both with o
r
Commiss
[ioners]
Instructions, and thereuppon o
r
pleasure is that you shall
re[.]
him to the States and Councell of State, and in all thing
to
[.]
of yo
r
power further the service now committed to him accord
[.]
Commission, and by yo
r
good advise to procure that the same
[.]
performed with the good will of the States and of the Cuntry
[.]
matter that percase at the first will not be plausible, but by
[.]
reasons as the said S
r
John Norris and yo
r
selfe may use to a
[.]
our request: we hope the same shall have good successe where
[.]
dition of tyme is of most moment to our purpose intended
under o
r
Signet at o
r
Manno
r
of Richmond the vjth daye
[Jan-]
uary
1590
in the xxxiijth yeare of o
r
raigne.
